The dark tone helps accentuate the character development as the characters hit their all time lows, and the film's tone represents that the world isn't always nice.The story for Empire Strikes Back, being the middle film in the trilogy, had the most freedom, and used it accordingly. The story of Empire Strikes back is arguably, the strongest in the series, as the film was one of the earliest to say the bad guy can win, in a giant blockbuster, another very ambitious move. However, the best element of the story is the unpredictable turns it makes, in particular it's iconic twist. The twist remains one of the most famous of all time, for a reason, and the film benefits from it.In the end Empire Strikes Back has the best story in the trilogy, the best character development, is very ambitious, and immortalizes it's iconic villain. On top of all of that it has been copied numerous times over the years, and remains one of the best films ever made. Empire Strikes Back still stands as the embodiment of what makes Star Wars so great.

title: The symbol for what a great sequel should be
content: The Empire Strikes Back is the most suspenseful, well-paced and most emotional entry of the Star Wars saga. It's the greatest of movie sequels and as far as it goes, it is everything a sequel to a great movie is supposed to be: a darker tone, more development with the characters, universe expanding with some new and greater additions and features.The perfect adventure telling story that continues from where it left off from and delved deeper into the characters we all know and love today and introduced bigger places in the galaxy far far away that George Lucas originally introduced to us. The action is stunning, the visuals still look ground-breaking today. Empire overall, is just the best movie sequel ever and I don't know if I can call it the best of the original trilogy because its a tough choice between the three of them, to me.But I still love The Empire Strikes Back so 10/10.

title: "Laugh it up fuzzball!"
content: Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back (1980) -Before I start the review of this film I will state that I do love it, because I love all of the Star Wars universe, especially the original trilogy, but also because it was a really well made film and it was delivered excellently in the same way as the first.I may ramble and reminisce a bit too much at times, not there should be some sort of point to it and actually that's the affect that these films have on a lot of people.This film didn't fall in to the usual trap of a sequel, with repetition and pointless continuation just for the sake of making money. It had some great moments, including laughs, action, space fighting, romance, the whole lot and with an original plot that continued the story because it needed to.I wouldn't have liked to have turned up to it without having seen 'Star Wars' (1977) beforehand and if you have to finish things off due to some sort of O. C. D., like I do, you will need to watch the next one, 'Star Wars: Return Of The Jedi' (1983) too, because this one ends on a cliffhanger.It works as Episode "V" of the original 3 (V, IV & VI - Ask George) and of the larger nonet that it became with the release of the Prequel Trilogy (1999/2002/2005?) and the more recent Sequels (2015/2017/2019) too and many regard it very highly on its own, but it certainly couldn't have been released or have been so successful without Episode IV, because I needed to know where they came from, who Ben was, why Luke had magic powers and so on.With that aside, I think that I mostly tend to appreciate this film, because I only remember seeing "IV" and "VI" on TV as a child, with maybe a few clips of this one, until my parents finally got a Video Cassette Player and of course the all important Cassettes to go with it, which came quite a bit later due to these highly popular productions actually being quite expensive back then.As a result I probably haven't seen this one as often as the other two, but feel a nostalgia based on a clearer teenage mind watching it almost new, as opposed to a 7 year old's memories of cute Teddy Bears (Ewoks) for instance.The story and the character development was great, because it meant that there was more of the universe that I already loved and I got to know my favourites better, whilst other great personalities like Lando Calrissian (Billy Dee Williams) and Yoda (Frank Oz) were introduced."Empire" actually had some of the better jokes, a great story and many of the classic moments that have since been turned in to memes. Harrison Ford looked mighty fine as Han Solo too.The update of the film, when it was digitally remastered, added some beautiful colours to places like Cloud City and clarity for the rest of the film. I also finally got to see more clearly what it was that attacked Luke at the beginning of the film, which, fun fact, was written in because of a car accident that he had in between recording, which left his face quite hideously disfigured.I also thought that they had realised that Harry had given them a lot more than they had expected in the first film and they seemed to have decided to expand his role in this one to make him more than just a roguish taxi driver. They later did the same, quite cleverly, with Poe (Oscar Isaac) and Finn (John Boyega) in the sequel films, because although the Jedi bit is great, the films have always relied on these additional characters to keep the action going in other ways while the young Padawan gets trained or has extended laser sword fights.The brilliance of this instalment was also added to by yet another superb soundtrack provided by John Williams, who managed to almost completely create something new, on top of the existing themes, but without it being far far away from the general style of sound already used.As far as I'm concerned, you can't go wrong with any of the Star Wars films (Skip 'The Last Jedi' - 2017), because they contain so much heart and a vast knowledge of the film history that had been collated in George Lucas' mind while he grew up. That was obvious with nods to many of the other great epic western, medieval, sci-fi and war films and tales that went before and of course the polish he delivered with each of the films in this series, not to forget the brilliance that came from his own imagination and the superb supporting special effects created by the ILM (Industrial Light & Magic) studios.I look at other films from the late 70's and early 80's and wonder why they didn't put as much in to it as the people that made this original trilogy, because it obviously worked if you want to create something that lasted.962.22/1000.

title: This is my very favorite movie!!  Bobafett is my favorite character
content: I love this movie dearly.  We find out Darth Vader is Luke's father, Han and Leia get together, and Boba Fett makes his appearance.  Let's not forget the wonderful Cloud City, Bespin, is first shown.

title: Cinema Personified: Brilliant Movie
content:
Rating: 9.7
Overall, a brilliant movie that really builds on where the last movie left off and improves on it in so many ways to make it a very memorable film that is not only the best in the series but in film history as we see a more mature Star Wars in the characters that take part in it.Great Direction (The actual moving of the story and making sure all pieces come together is incredible managed and executed, and this movie is a definite improvement in directing people than its predecessor as the director was really able to get more out of his actors in their performances for this time around), Very Good to Great Acting (Very Good from the Live-Action Cast; Great from the Vocal/Costumed-Characters) (Very Good from Mark Hamill (showed the progress he has made from being a naive/hopeful kid to someone more cognizant of the present and the work he needs to put in to be a better Jedi), Great from Harrison Ford (the real star of the show in all his scenes as he smooth/cool nature really helps show how great of a character Han Solo really is (and he really cleaned up the delivery of his lines in this movie as there are not any awkward pauses as there were last time), Good to Very Good from Carrie Fisher (She really improves this time around as she is given more freedom to play as opposed to last time; she also really grows as a character from being the damsel in distress to being a loving leader), Good to Very Good from Billy Dee Williams (Really becomes a memorable presence in all the scenes he is in with his cool nature that conflicts/competes with Han, though there is some hiccups in delivery as he is still getting used to the Star Wars universe as opposed to the other members of the cast), Very Good from Anthony Daniels (really brings C-3PO to life as he tries to help but panics in not knowing how much he can (the anxious nerd-savior trope); also, plays a great role in helping vocalize the relationship and friendship he has with R2-D2), Incredible from James Earl Jones/David Prowse (created one of the most iconic voices in pop-culture as his menacing voice and performance showed why Darth Vader is a villain to be scared of), Incredible from Kenny Baker (Really brings R2 to life through the difference mannerisms the character has in sort of a comedic relief yet important way (making R2 one of the best characters in all of Star Wars); also, helps bring the flare that makes the character's friendship with C-3PO one of the best in pop-culture), Very Good from Peter Mayhew (Played the adorable, yet extremely dangerous Chewie and played off his co-star very nicely, similar to the R2/C-3PO relationship; and really grows the character to show how loving he is towards his new friends), Great to Incredible from Frank Oz (Really brought the character of Yoda to life with the puppeteering and the vocal performance, Good to Very Good from the rest of the Live-Action cast; Very Good from the rest of the Vocal/Costumed-Characters cast), Incredible Story (Really sets up different elements of the universe very nicely and uses the concept of parallel storylines very well; also has some of the most iconic moments of the series and does a good job in building the downfall of the characters; the only issue this time around is that it does not have the ability to build worlds like the previous film could), Great Screenplay (The dialogue this time around felt way more natural and was better written; the screenplay still shines is the foreshadowing to future Star Wars events, symbolism, iconic lines (with it having one of the most iconic lines/plot twists in cinema (or even narrative) history)), Brilliant Score (Takes what was great from the previous film and adds some new themes that really make this score stand out as well), Great to Incredible Cinematography (Which really stands out in the Luke vs. Vader scene), Very Good Sound (Especially when giving the movie a space/science-fiction feel as well as bringing the sounds of the droids (especially R2-D2) to life, but there are some issues with Sound in this movie as there feels like a delayed sound with the lightsabers (which is very annoying if you have watched the prequels)), Very Good to Great Editing, Very Good Visual Effects (This movie does not really go overboard with the new visuals of the re-release as much as the other movies so it is easier to comment on), Incredible to Brilliant Production Design (Created some very iconic sets that are well remembered in history, and really added to that with the Hoth/Dagobah/Bespin sets which are regarded as some of the best in all of Star Wars), Incredible Makeup (Helped bring to life aliens that are not from this world), Incredible Costumes (Created some of the most iconic outfits in pop-culture history, with the Darth Vader costume being one of the most well remembered in any historical context), Plot Structure was very well written as it has three major parallel story lines that all converge to the climax and the end (something that helps keep the audience engaged to see how the different arcs are coming along), Pacing was better in this movie as it felt more consistent and not as slow as the last one, Build to climax is done very nicely as it is really pivots the franchise into seeing who these characters really are as they have to make important decisions for the future; Climax was the best part of the movie as we get to see what Luke's training has come to/seeing the rest of the crew into action as we get to see how much the characters have grown yet see how far they really are to their goals in the sage; moreover one of the most important lines in history is delivered in this climax that make Star Wars a franchise memorable, Tone does not play as much into the space opera or science fiction epic as the last one but does have shades of it; feels more like a standout movie that really transcends genre in many ways (while still keeping the same star wars charm), Really can be felt of as a stand alone movie (even though it leaves so much to be answered with its ending) as we get to see the rise and fall of the characters as they must continue their own individual quests to grow as characters.

title: May the rose-tinted glasses be with you
content: Not for the life of me do I understand how people think this is better than its predecessor. Yes it has its moments but there is a distinct drop in quality, not least when it comes to the special effects. At times it looks like watching a close up of toy spaceships being moved around on fishing wire.The development of Skywalker is poor throughout these films and is particularly bad here. His progression from outer-galactic farmhand to Jedi Knight is laughably far-fetched and just doesn't seem feasible. His tutelage under Yoda is under-done and the use of 'The Force' as a plot band-aid is tiresome and insincere, a clear example of Lucas' often childish writing.The battle scenes were poor in A New Hope but get even worse in Empire Strikes Back. Very poor choreography and, even for 1980, pretty amateurish special effects. Did people really find the battle between Skywalker and Vader in any way engaging? I honestly just don't get it.There is plenty to admire about this film and it's certainly not the worst sequel ever made but a classic it is surely not.

title: It's easy to say. It's more difficult to explane: The best movie ever made
content: The saga continues (please excuse me for some dumb spelling mistakes, they just got here)... The first Star Wars movie didn't really turn me into a deep star wars fanatic, but I must say, theese three movies are my absolute favorites!The second (or fifth, whatever it is the same anyway) part of the trilogy, ''The Empire Strikes Back'' is just as good as all the others. At some points it is more of a direct remake of the first movie, but mostly it is new profiles and new stories to experience. I thought the rescuing of an innocent princess was magic. Boy! Here (for those who did not knew) Luke gets to the ''Dagobah-system'' to find the Jedi-master Yoda, Obi Wan's master. There he will learn to suffer hard training, and wild adventures until he finnaly meets the master of darkness, Darth Vader. In the same leap goes Han Solo's adventure in Lando Calrissian's city in the clouds, together with Chewie, Leia, C3PO and R2-D2. It's pure magic, and that special effects got better after three years didn't make things worse. I love theese films. May them live forever!

title: The most overrated movie in history
content: After a strong start at the Battle of Hoth, the entire movie takes a turn to extremely boring.Say what you will about the Prequels, at least they had highly climactic battles to keep anybody invested the whole way through.

title: "No, I am your father"
content:
The Empire Strikes Back expands upon the established world of Star Wars without forgetting what made the first movie so amazing. The effects are just as enthralling as they were in Star Wars (if not more so), as shown in the amazing new worlds that Empire introduces (Hoth, Cloud City, Dagobah), and John Williams once again blows us away with a score that is on par with his work in the previous movie.
The story takes us in a different direction than Star Wars, giving the audience a greater insight into the workings of the Empire and Darth Vader's character. Vader's arc culminates in his iconic confrontation with Luke Skywalker at Cloud City, which ends with possibly the greatest twist in movie history.
Empire's story is more mature than its predecessor, and leading actors have matured and greatly improved as well (props to Mark Hamill, who did about half of his scenes with a puppet and still made them believable). The dialogue is sharp, the camera work is clean, and new iconic characters get to shine in this movie. I especially loved when Yoda gave his explanation of what the force is, increasing the audience's understanding without removing any its mysticism.
Overall, this movie expertly balances pretty much every aspect it should. The acting, the visual set pieces, the sound design, the score, and the story all shine, combining to create a masterpiece of a movie.10/10

title: The Best Star Wars Film
content: When the movie first came out in 1980, fans and critics weren't a big fan over the films more mature tones compared to Star Wars (1977). But since then, critics and fans, including i, have redeemed the movie as the best Star Wars movie, and one of my favorite, sci-fi, and sequel movies, and one of my personal favorites. It is alongside with Terminator 2: Judgment Day and Aliens (1986), one of the greatest sequels of all time. The movie looks better than most CGI-Hollywood films today, and this was made in 1980!, and was made entirely without CGI. The movie stars Mark Hamill, Harrison Ford, Carrie Fisher, Billy Dee Williams, Anthony Daniels, David Prowse, Kenny Baker, Peter Mayhew, and Frank Oz. 10/10, totally recommend it, to every movie fan.

title: Even better than the first one and rightfully a highly beloved and cherished part of popular culture!
content: When I was a kid and was years away from watching "Star Wars" franchise myself, I was watching a soccer game with my dad and I distinctly remember that the commentator said "The empire strikes back." when a goal was scored against our country. I am not from USA, I am from Croatia. And I can guarantee you most of the adults who heard that understood the reference. That alone should tell you how much this movie is beloved and immortalized in popular culture. Even though the first movie was a giant success, this didn't mean making the sequel was easy. There were, again, problems with the budget and with filming and editing, but, in the end, we still received an amazing movie due to imagination of George Lucas and the talent of the people working on the movie! This time, the plot is faster, more focused and darker than in the first movie, but the whole thing is still very entertaining and fills you with warmth only movies made with a lot of effort, care and love put into them can. Basically, if you weren't won over by the first movie, there's nothing here to change your mind for the worse and you can only be impressed. But if you didn't like these movies in the first place, you wouldn't be reading this random review from some guy from Croatia, yet here you are, waiting for some random stranger to praise this movie for bazzilionth time. And don't worry, I will! "Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back" is, same as the first movie, a timeless masterpiece that offers an entertaining and emotional adventure full of wonder, fun and action, which will be enjoyed by all future generations of science fiction fans! 10/10! Watch it, enjoy it and thank God, George Lucas, Harrison Ford, Mark Hamill, Carrie Fisher and everyone else who worked on it! Thank you for making our lives better by letting us experience this saga! May the force be with you, wherever you are!

title: One of the Best
content: This is one of my all time favorite movies! My kids are also lifelong fans of these movies!! Thanks For Making Some Great Family Films

title: The best of the "Star Wars" films
content: No matter what you think 'defines' "Star Wars"- the action sequences, the detailed and enthralling mythos, the memorable characters, the romance, or just the atmosphere of adventure, "The Empire Strikes Back" is in just about every way the most rewarding viewing experience out of any of the six live action "Star Wars" films (I have not seen "Clone Wars" and don't intend to right now). Why? Because it pulls off what "Revenge of the Sith" failed at: creating a compelling and well-written character-driven story while still delivering plenty of action, humor, and remaining an homage to the serials of the 1930's and 40's.It's surprising that there remains debate over how right or wrong critics were on the film at the time of its release, when it received not negative nor very positive reviews, but mixed ones leaning towards the positive side, generally. Few critics initially recognized the superiority of this screenplay to the first film in the series, and not only its relative complexity but its richness in its allusions to and utilization of literature and films of the past to create its own unique mythos. It's hardly surprising, given that Leigh Brackett was involved in writing the screenplay, some of her greatest achievements in her film career being "The Big Sleep", "The Long Goodbye", and "Rio Bravo", all rich, detailed, and intelligent screenplays.Yes, attempting to argue that "The Empire Strikes Back" is an intelligent character-based film is fast becoming pointless; you're either preaching to the choir or attempting to convince those with the prequels fresh in their mind that "Star Wars" was, once upon a time, a franchise worthy of real praise. "The Empire Strikes Back" really does tell a compelling story, however, and it is compelling mostly because we really do care about Luke's journey, we do care about Han Solo, we love Chewie, we adore the banter between R2-D2 and C-3PO, and arguably most of all because Darth Vader isn't just a 'cool' villain, he's a genuinely interesting and compelling character (er, if you can keep Hayden Christensen out of mind). Lawrence Kasdan and Leigh Brackett have achieved something rare and special here, a grand Hollywood spectacle which can be analyzed and discussed at great length (which I'm definitely not going to do, if you're interested pick up one of the dozens, hundreds possibly, of books written on the subject, or just do a quick Google search) . It's a great screenplay.Not that there haven't been great screenplays let down by incompetent film-making in the past, but "The Empire Strikes Back" is certainly not an example of this. I'm sure "Star Wars" fans know much more about the making of this film and how much credit Irvin Kershner deserves for the end result than I do, but for this review I'll credit him with the quality of this film on a technical level. It's an improvement over the first film in many ways, as far as I'm concerned, especially the set design (which is more ambitious here), and the quality of the visuals and even the acting. "Star Wars" may have an opening scene and shot which remains magical to this day, but I'd argue that most of this film is memorable and enthralling, with only one or two scenes in the first half hour or so being just 'good'. The acting also improves notably, with the exception of Carrie Fisher (who really just isn't a good actor), Mark Hamill is arguably the most improved since the first film, really coming into his own as Luke Skywalker here, and even giving us one of cinema's few good 'NOOO!!!' moments. "The Empire Strikes Back" also introduces us to Yoda, of course, and I'm really surprised at how animated and expressive Yoda is (being, I'm pretty sure, a puppet at this point). The special effects in general are outstanding, outside of a couple of the creatures near the beginning of the film.It's not just that "The Empire Strikes Back" is an enthralling and exciting film, and an iconic one at that, but it really does work on a deeper level. No, I'm not saying that "The Empire Strikes Back" is some sort of immeasurably complex and subtle film, but what's impressive about it is that it offers spectacle and humor, but is also a genuinely compelling tale driven by its characters, primarily Luke. It's a great, great movie, and where "Star Wars" may fall just short of deserving the sort of praise it gets, "The Empire Strikes Back" really is a terrific movie and deserves all the praise it has received and will receive in the future.9.5/10

title: One of the worst in the history and OMG so much overrated
content: The Star Wars movies were the worst movies of all time.Science fiction by itself is bad enough, let alone being a cult-like nerd flick.The music was the best thing, and even that was melodramatic at timesAnd come on, what's the whole "long time ago" thing. If we don't have flying machines now, we most certainly didn't have them in the pastOK, so maybe the Star Wars movies don't belong on the bottom 100, but in the top ten is ridiculous.First, the movie does not have a proper ending . It just stops when all the battles have finished and do not explain any other things after the battle. Instead, it only shows a shot of the characters looking out the window. This really disappoints me. Second, about the love between Princess Leia and Han Solo. I have never thought that Leia and Han Solo are a couple until they suddenly kiss. It makes me feel very surprised because the movie does not show any obvious relation between them. Third, the movie does not tell story but showing a battle sequence instead. It is very boring for audience to watch. Finally, the battle of Luke and Darth Vader did not bring out a mood of climax but instead it makes me think that "It is ridiculous."

title: The best movie in an overrated franchise
content: 40 years later and Disney with all of it billions of dollars still can't make a Star Wars film that comes close to this.

title: Star Wars, The mother of Science Fiction
content: I am a chain si-fi movie watcher. What ever I can remember, Stars Wars is the base of all science Fiction movie from Hollywood. All of these things come into play in my position, but I'm mostly analyzing my picks on the effect they had on me, both when I actually formerly viewed them and today. As always, I actually appreciate your feedback in the section below, but most of all, would want to see your rating of the films. With out further delay, on to the list

title: My 1st film now I'm 40 : A retrospective - The Empire Strikes Back
content: When I was six, two incredibly creative ladies, a mother and daughter babysitting duo named Phillise and Mary Frances, not only introduced me to the imaginative art of Michael Whelan, but they also screened for me my very first vhs; The Empire Strikes Back.To say this experience was life changing is no understatement, especially now as I watch the film again at 40. In fact, it's themes, archetypes and narrative, are even more relatable now as someone even further along their own story.Cinephiles such as yourself, will know, that George Lucas crafted something in consult with his friend and professional academic Joseph Campbell.Joseph John Campbell (March 26, 1904 - October 30, 1987) was an American writer. He was a professor of literature at Sarah Lawrence College who worked in comparative mythology and comparative religion. His work covered many aspects of the human experience and his best-known work is his book 'The Hero with a Thousand Faces' (1949), in which he discusses his theory of the journey of the archetypal hero shared by world mythologies, termed the monomyth.So at the root of the Star Wars story, one still growing with shows like Andor and a new slate under the guidance of Dave Filony and George Lucas once again , is a notion that perhaps this film has the clout and revere it does because the creators succeeded at hiding the vegetables in the cheese in a way no other film has and with such meaningful permanence.The subtext of the film, if open to the idea that films have a subtext and social historical context, is that the Director and writer were performing the age old ritual of offering up a universal story to a scared village. Story serves this purpose in its many forms, including cinema. It brings us together in community so we can escape from the trauma of reality and basked in allegorized aslects if life, projected up on the screen in the same way shamans told and still tell stories by fire or projector light.As you get older and life begins to offer up new existential buffets of fear and death, The Empire Strikes Back, and its tone, plot, themes, performances, lighting, score and subtext, seem to take on even greater meaning. Perhaps the most poignant being the portrayal of things that do actually happen to families and people who living in worlds where empires and villains and there choices can test the individual psyche in ways only Luke Skywalker could know.For me, dealing with the 7 month decline of my mother with brain cancer and witnessing the lack of care and resources for her before and during the pandemic, felt like I was up against evil forces far greater than me. The test of seeing her suffer in a broken healthcare system in crisis, and then being placated by administrators, doctors, nurses and ceos aware of the resource issues and poor care but unable to agree or admit and unwilling to do anything about it, pit me in a psychological battle that tested my wits and strength in ways that made me the worse version of myself, one who was angry. The struggle to deal with anger, much like Anakin Skywalker and Luke Skywalkers, is the struggle to deal with emotions in the face of injustice, but not just any injustice, injustice that claims one's family.If we look at the present state of the world, one cannibalizing itself in misinformation, political scandal, war, environmental collapse, mental health crisis, the disappearance of the middle class, the rise of fanaticism, the phenomenon of mass shootings, broken healthcare and education systems, nuclear proliferation, pandemics, and perhaps the greatest threat, the unregulated advance and public experiment of A. I., well it certainly does seem like age of evil empires and heroes up against unspeakable odds and bad actors.This is why at 40, with all that's happened since I first watched the film at 6, the story continues to gains in importance and meaning. Yes it's just a silly space opera, but it also represents every persons own struggle against forces they cannot control. Welding the force represents obtaining balance, and in real life, balance is a myth. We all want to be Jedi's, we all want our families to just be safe and get along, we all want to be loved, we all want to live on as force ghosts, and we all want an Ewok baby to cuddle.

title: A good but boring sequel to A New Hope
content: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back is often described by movie critics and fans as the best Star Wars film of all time. It is undoubtedly a film of its own class.However, I think that this film contains very lengthy and boring sequences, especially in the middle of the film, such as the Dagobah and Bespin scenes. Viewers who are watching this film for the second or third time may find these scenes to be rather long and boring, as they already know is going to happen later on in the film.
